title: Simple traffic lights going in opposite directions
content: In this tutorial you will learn how to create two simple traffic lights going in opposite directions

Select **RGBLamp** to transform your smartphone in a rgb lamp

![simple lamp](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/Devices/Items/RGBLamp-Item.png)

this will be used as a traffic light

Scan the QR code with your smartphone.

![QrCode](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/qrscan.png)

Alternatively, click on _Open in this device_ to open the rgb lamp locally.

Move the **set-colour** component into the workspace

![QrCode](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/simple-traffic-lights/set-colour.png)

this component will allow us to set a color (using the rgb system colour) in our traffic light

Press devices again, select **RGBLamp**

![simple lamp](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/Devices/Items/RGBLamp-Item.png)
to generate a second RGBLamp.

Press on your smartphone **Add another input/output via QR code**

![simple lamp](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/Devices/Add-another-input-output-via-qr.jpeg)
and scan the QR code. Alternatively, click on _Open in this device_ to open it locally.

Now let's simulate the traffic lights in opposite direction. Set green color in the first traffic light and red color in the second traffic light, as in the image below

![QrCode](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/simple-traffic-lights/set-colours.png)

Now we need to simulate that certain seconds pass and the traffic lights change color, for this we will use the wait component, which allows us to leave our program waiting for a certain amount of time.

Press ![input](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/Timing/Timing.png) on the sidebar

Press ![add output](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/Timing/delay-component.png) button,
move it to the workspace and set the amount of time the program should wait to change the color of the lights

![QrCode](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/simple-traffic-lights/wait.png)

As before, you have to set the traffic lights to the corresponding color, move to the workspace the component to set the color of each of the lamps, and set yellow color in the first traffic light and green color in the second traffic light.

![QrCode](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/simple-traffic-lights/set-colours2.png)

Once again, we need to simulate that certain seconds pass and the traffic lights change color

![QrCode](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/simple-traffic-lights/wait2.png)

One more time, repeat the process to set the traffic light colors to the corresponding colors and add the wait component, in general you should have something like in the image below

![QrCode](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/simple-traffic-lights/set-colours3.png)

in the next step we will make the traffic light cycle repeat itself

To repeat the traffic light cycle we will use the main loop component, which allows us to re-run the code after it has finished executing.

Press ![input](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/Loops/Loops.png) on the sidebar.

Then, move to the workspace the
![input](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/Loops/main-loop-component.png)
component and place it as shown in the picture

![QrCode](https://github.com/bellinux/tutorial-protobject/raw/main/images/simple-traffic-lights/main-loop.png)
